On board were Roscosmos cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev and NASA astronaut Bill Shepherd. They were known as Expedition 1, the first long-term crew to live on the ISS. The company plans to utilize the facility for the mass production of electronic components for space applications. The TechniSat facility in Schöneck was established in June 1992 and currently employs around […]

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy November 2-8, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of November 2-8, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The Senate is in session this week. […]
detailed_news: This week marks the 25th anniversary of permanent occupancy of the International Space Station. The Senate is in session this week. The House continues to be in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. NASA wants commercial companies to step forward with commercial space stations where NASA can be just one of many customers. At other events this week, representatives from those companies will be sharing their plans. It’s day 33 of the partial government shutdown. House Speaker Mike Johnson decided on Friday to keep the House out of legislative session for yet another week. The shutdown can only end if enough Senate Democrats/Independents decide to vote with most Republicans. There are quite a few interesting events here and overseas. There are lots of great meetings and conferences on tap this week. We highlight a few names that probably are familiar to the readers of this website. There does not appear to be a virtual option. Check back throughout the week for others we learn about later and add to our Calendar.

title: Live coverage: Commercial space station demo, data center precursor to launch on SpaceX Bandwagon mission
summary: SpaceX will fly 18 payloads to a mid-inclination orbit including an intelligence-gathering satellite for the military of South Korea. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is set for 1:09 a.m. EDT (0509 UTC).
detailed_news: Bandwagon-4, is the fourth multi-customer flight to a mid-inclination orbit and the 18th mission as part of SpaceX’s small sat ride share program. The mission will use Falcon 9 first stage booster B1091, which will eventually fly as a center booster for a Falcon Heavy rocket. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 95 percent chance for favorable weather at liftoff with just a small chance for interference from cumulus clouds. Starcloud believes that its future space-based data centers can be “ten times cheaper than land-based options” Philip Johnston predicted that “In 10 years, nearly all new data centers will be being built in outer space” Germany-based Exolaunch is responsible for manifesting and deploying 13 out of the 18 payloads flying.

title: Starship Block 3 and HLS: The Path to Get Back to the Moon
summary:
Amid numerous questions about whether SpaceX can have the Human Landing System (HLS) variant of…
The post Starship Block 3 and HLS: The Path to Get Back to the Moon appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX recently released an update regarding Starship and its Human Landing System variant. This variant of the Starship is set to be one of the landers for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s (NASA) Artemis program. The ship will operate alongside tankers and depots to refuel, enabling it to deliver not only people but also approximately 100 tons of cargo to the lunar surface. SpaceX has completed 49 milestones so far in the development of HLS. Docking adapter qualification has been achieved in conjunction with NASA and Lockheed. Landing leg testing, which included the dropping of a full-scale article at flight energies onto simulated lunar regolith, has also been completed. SpaceX currently has two test tanks at their Masseys test area. The first full flight test of Block 3 is scheduled to involve Booster 18 and Ship 39 and is expected to launch sometime in Quarter 1 of 2026. Currently, neither vehicle is complete in construction, and, based on the best timelines using past boosters and ships as reference points, neither will likely begin cryogenic proof testing until December. Ship 39 has a few noticeable changes, even though it is only a couple of sections into stacking. SpaceX has refined the design of the ship catch pins and relocated them to the nosecone. The common dome has moved down slightly, which means SpaceX will be able to load more LCH4 into the tank. Another significant addition is a probe-and-drogue docking system.

The post Thales Alenia Space Clears Key Milestone for In-Orbit Servicing Demo appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: A group of companies led by Thales Alenia Space has completed the System Preliminary Design Review for Italy’s In-Orbit Servicing (IOS) demonstration mission. The IOS mission will involve demonstrating a wide range of in-orbit servicing applications, including refuelling, component repair or replacement, orbital transfer, and atmospheric re-entry.

title: China Launches New Space Station Crew
summary: China launched a new three-person crew to their Tiangong-3 space station today. Shenzhou-21 lifted off at 11:44 am EDT and arrived at the space station about three hours later where […]
detailed_news: China launched a new three-person crew to their Tiangong-3 space station today. Accompanying the Shenzhou-21 crew are four mice, the first time rodents will be aboard a Chinese space station. Today is the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Russian-American crew that initiated permanent occupancy of the ISS. The ISS was mostly assembled over 12 years (1998-2010) and currently has a mass of about 420 Metric Tons. ISS is much larger than Tiangong-3, although China plans to expand it in coming years. title: Elon Musk on data centers in orbit: “SpaceX will be doing this”
summary: "We could see another transformation of what’s done in space."
detailed_news: Elon Musk says Starlink satellites could be used to build data centers in space. Musk’s interest in space-based data centers significantly raises the profile of the nascent industry. Proponents of the idea say the advantages are clear: free, limitless power from the Sun and none of the messy environmental costs of building these facilities on Earth. The first operational Starlink satellites launched a little more than half a decade ago with a mass of about 300 kg and a capacity of 15Gbps. Starlink V3 satellites will likely mass 1,500 kg. Ars Technica has been separating the signal from the noise for over 25 years.

summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: From September to October 2025, the entire ESA astronaut reserve cohort completed a second phase of training at ESA’s European Astronaut Centre. The exercise involved mastering protective equipment, handling high-pressure hoses and CO₂ extinguishers, and practising escape and rescue techniques. The group will return in early 2026 for the final training phase.

summary: What began with tragedy ended in triumph. This is the untold story of the European Space Agency’s pioneering 25-year Cluster mission to study how invisible solar storms impact Earth's environment.

title: China prepares to launch crewed Shenzhou-21 mission
summary:
China is preparing to send its tenth crew to the Tiangong space station. This will…
The post China prepares to launch crewed Shenzhou-21 mission appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: China is preparing to send its tenth crew to the Tiangong space station. The Shenzhou-21 mission is scheduled to launch aboard a Chang Zheng 2F/G (CZ-2F) on Friday, Oct. 31. This will be the 16th crewed spaceflight for China’s Shenzhou program overall, which has continually occupied the orbiting outpost since June 2021. Shenzhou 20 is China's second mission to the Tiangong 1 space station. The CZ-2F rocket has the capacity to lift 8,400 kg to low-Earth orbit. The Shenzhou spacecraft has a larger internal habitable volume than the Soyuz spacecraft, and is similarly limited to three crew. Shenzhou-20 crew will return to Earth in early November. Crew may even exceed the longest single-mission stay of 192 days, set by Shenzhou-18 in 2024. Commander Chen Dong is the first taikonaut to spend over 400 days in space. The new crew will spend around six months on the station.

title: Earth from Space: Ghostly lake
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Lake Carnegie lies at the southwestern border of the Gibson Desert in the Shire of Wiluna in Western Australia. When full, its total area is around 5700 sq km, making it one of Australia’s biggest lakes. These images were captured after unusually high rainfall in the region, making the lake's ghostly ‘face’ easily seen from space.

title: Flickering flame: spooky spirits or serious science?
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The experiment took place during the European Space Agency’s parabolic flight campaign in September. Parabolic flights are a way of temporarily creating a microgravity environment without venturing so far from Earth. During 93 parabolas spread over three flights, candles made from different waxes and with various wicks were lit, placed in a sealed box, and closely observed by the experiment operators.

title: EnduroSat Secures $104M in New Funding to Boost Production Capacity
summary:
Bulgarian satellite manufacturer EnduroSat has secured $104 million in new funding to ramp up its small satellite manufacturing capacity. […]
The post EnduroSat Secures $104M in New Funding to Boost Production Capacity appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Bulgarian satellite manufacturer EnduroSat has secured $104 million in new funding to ramp up its small satellite manufacturing capacity. Once operating at full capacity, the new production facility will be capable of manufacturing two 200–500 kg satellites per day. According to the company, this expanded capacity will enable it to meet the growing global demand for small- to medium-sized satellite constellations.

title: SpaceX ramps up Starship preparations at Florida’s Roberts Road

authors.name: Alejandro Alcantarilla Romera and Chris Bergin

summary:
SpaceX is making significant strides in developing its Starship infrastructure at the Roberts Road facilities.…
The post SpaceX ramps up Starship preparations at Florida’s Roberts Road appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is making significant strides in developing its Starship infrastructure at the Roberts Road facilities. NSF aerial photography has revealed rapid progress on key components, including the LC-39A launch mount. Starship is set to debut from the Space Coast in 2026, initially from the historic 39A, all while two launch pads are built at SLC-37. Tower modules 1 through 7 are now complete, with early sections receiving outfitting. Progress also extends to the new Starship launch tower being staged at Roberts Road. In just five weeks, two tower cranes have been erected and are actively assembling beams and columns, with construction reaching two floors in some areas.

Planned future […]
The post The Exploration Company Opens New HQ in Oberpfaffenhofen appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: In-space logistics startup The Exploration Company has opened its new headquarters in Oberpfaffenhofen, Germany. The company is developing a modular, reusable spacecraft called Nyx, which will initially be used to transport cargo to and from the International Space Station. Planned future variants of the spacecraft include versions capable of transporting cargo to lunar orbit and the surface of the Moon.

title: An in-space construction firm says it can help build massive data centers in orbit
summary: "Size is not the limit anymore."
detailed_news: A new in-space assembly company, Rendezvous Robotics, announced an agreement to explore the use of modular, autonomous assembly. The company’s technology is based on research by Ariel Ekblaw, who led development of a self-assembling tile technology called Project TESSERAE. Starcloud and Rendezvous are teaming up to build space-based AI data centers. There is a long way to go, of course, but there is funding available for companies that can meet the infrastructure demands of AI data center in the near future. Perhaps space is the place.

title: Former NASA Administrators urge space agency to rethink plans for Artemis Moon lander
summary: The comments came during a fireside chat featuring former NASA administrators, Charlie Bolden and Jim Bridenstine, at the conclusion of the American Astronautical Society’s 2025 von Braun Space Exploration Symposium in Huntsville, Alabama.
detailed_news: Charles Bolden and Jim Bridenstine were speaking at the American Astronautical Society’s 2025 von Braun Space Exploration Symposium in Huntsville, Alabama. The former NASA Administrators called on the space agency to rethink its plans to land astronauts on the Moon using SpaceX's Starship. They said development of the revolutionary vehicle was taking too long and required unnecessary complexity. Bridenstine argued that the current architecture using Starship for Artemis 3 crewed landing means that the “probability of beating China approaches zero rapidly” He suggested a more Apollo-style route of launching both Orion and the lander on one flight of the SLS rocket equipped with the Exploration Upper Stage being built by Boeing. Liftoff came on the heels of leaders from the U.S. Space Force gathering to discuss how to adjust to a rapidly increasing launch cadence for both the Eastern Range and Western Range. “Since it’s definitely a competitive environment, I probably won’t say too much about it, but we did just kick off that work with NASA,” Cortese said.

title: Former NASA administrators call for changes in Artemis lunar lander architecture

Two former NASA administrators criticized the agency’s current use of SpaceX’s Starship for the Artemis 3 crewed lunar landing, calling for an urgent redirection to reach the moon before China.
The post Former NASA administrators call for changes in Artemis lunar lander architecture appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: Sentinel-1D pre-launch media briefing
summary: Follow the online briefing on the launch scheduled for 4 November 2025. The Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission delivers radar images of Earth’s surface. It is vital for disaster response teams, environmental agencies, maritime authorities, climate scientists.
